doc.title: 3Q25 PERFORMANCE
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/Agilent 3Q25 Strong organic growth shows continued market recoveryAgilent 3Q25 Strong organic growth shows continued mar_2025-08-28

passages.text: Agilent reported 3Q25 results after market Wednesday (PR, slides). Core revenue growth of \(6.1\%\) was meaningfully above guidance of \(1.7\% - 3.6\%\) and consensus of \(2.9\%\) ; adj. EPS of \(\) 1.37\(was at the high end of guidance and in - line with consensus.

Strong signals of continued improvement in market health: Agilent's print demonstrated a continued recovery that is consistent (saw fifth consecutive quarter of sequential core revenue acceleration) and widespread (A&G returned to \(1\%\) growth; Pharma saw \(9\%\) growth; Environ. & Forensics was the only one to decline, down a modest \(5\%\) ). Mgmt also noted that approvals of CapEx purchases are coming more easily; they stated, "there is reduced dependence on executive- level approvals that have slowed or stopped spending in the recent past." Finally, mgmt commentary reinforced that pharma are not making cuts amidst the uncertain environment ("we're not seeing any concerns translate into negative impact around MFN or tariffs at all"), which we believe was one of the most important messages to come out of 2Q.

Margins were weaker than anticipated, but the weakness is more of a positive sign than it seems at first glance: Mgmt attributed the margin weakness (adj. operating margin was \(\sim 150\) bps below consensus, and down \(\sim 230\) bps YoY) to three things: 1) Higher revenues and demand driving up net tariff and logistics costs; 2) Increased variable pay expectations; and 3) Incremental commercial investment. All of these factors exist only because the company's performance and expectations for 4Q have improved. For example, accruing more variable pay means that sales are higher than expected, and increases in investments mean that the company expects a continued upward trajectory. The company is investing early in market recovery to capture share in both its own and competitors' accounts.

The company raised the guide for core revenue growth by a hefty \(1.5p.p.\) at the midpoint, but it is still very achievable: The guide implies \(\sim 26.5\%\) of revenue in 4Q (vs. the \(\sim 27\%\) average), leaving room for a budget flush that is weaker- than- average.
The stock was - flat after market; we think this represents too much focus on the negatives and not enough on the positives. We maintain our MP rating and our \(\) 125\(PT. Model: A

Just want the most critical information, or our take on the "so what?" coming out of earnings? That's on the first page, and you should stop reading here. But want a more complete accounting of what happened? See detailed recaps of Agilent's 3Q25 performance, their FY25 guidance, and their commentary on the geographies / end markets / product types / other notable things. We also throw in a one- table view of our model updates and some useful graphical views of Agilent's business.
The most useful recap view is (we think) what we're calling the "Company Commentary Tracker" - sets of tables that capture two things:

1. How narratives across the sector are evolving during 3Q about the things that matter (e.g., what do the companies that have already reported have to say about the drivers of demand weakness that we're calling the 5 boogeymen? the end markets? the geographies?)

2. A reminder of Agilent's commentary over time (e.g., want to remember which quarters were hit most by the COVID lockdown, or when instruments started getting so bad, so you can keep that in mind as you're thinking about where the tough comps are?)

The company commentary tracker is updated every day after earnings with the relevant company's information. The tracker contains information for our covered companies (TMO, AVTR, A, WAT, RVTY) plus a broader set of relevant but not covered peers including life sciences and instruments (Danaher, Bio- Techne, Bio- Rad, Bruker, Mettler- Toledo); bioprocessing equipment (Sartorius, Repligen); CDMOs (Lonza); and CROs (IQVIA, ICON, MEDP).
EXHIBIT 1: **Agilent** **results** **vs.** **Bernstein** **and** **consensus**

Agilent raised their FY25 revenue guidance:
EXHIBIT 3: A FY25 guidance
Source: Company reports, Bernstein analysis
In addition to the key metrics highlighted above, Agilent also shared the additional points on FY25 guidance:
Net interest and other income / expense: \(\) 26M\$
Diluted share counts of 285M for the full year

Tariff: now expecting \(\) 20M\(net cost for the year, increased from the previous guidance in May. The increase is due to better than expected revenue performance in H2 and\) 50\% \(tariff increase on imports from Europe announced at the beginning of August.
Agilent issued guidance for 4Q25:
EXHIBIT 4: A 4Q25 guidance
4Q25 guidanceNet revenue ($M)$1,822 - $1,842Core revenue growth+4.8% to +6.0%FX impact+0.2%M&amp;A impact+2.1%Adj. EPS$1.57 - $1.60
Source: Company reports, Bernstein analysis
In addition to the key metrics highlighted above, Agilent also shared the additional points on 4Q25 guidance:
Net interest and other income / expense: \(\) 9M\$ Diluted share counts of 284M Expect sequential margin improvement of \(\sim 230\) bps End market growth

- Pharma: expect M/HSD growth with stable to improving conditions- Chemicals & Advanced Materials: expect HSD growth- Diagnostics & Clinicals and Food: expect MSD growth- Environmental & Forensics: expect very low LSD growth- Academia & Government: expect MSD decline, as these markets will face a difficult comp with US federal spending at the end of the FY
- Americas grew \(5\%\) .
- Europe grew \(7\%\) .
- Asia ex China grew \(10\%\) , with India growing \(20\%\) across end markets.

- China grew \(4\%\) . Business was stable as expected. Saw some government funding flow to some academic and government customers during the quarter. The company continue to expect a more meaningful stimulus impact towards the end of the calendar year, particularly in the applied markets. The diagnostic business has very low exposure in China, which has seen minimal VBP impact.

- Pharma grew \(9\%\) , with small molecule growing DD from downstream QA/QC demand and Infinity III adoption. Biopharma grew HSD, but was flat ex-NASD as US biopharma spending continues to be muted (in line with expectations).- Chemicals & Advanced Materials revenue grew \(10\%\) , with balanced growth between Advanced Materials as well as Chemical and Energy.- Food grew \(7\%\) , benefiting from strength in Asia through increasing safety regulations.- Environmental & Forensics declined \(5\%\) due to changes in the US EPA, which led to CapEx spending cautiousness.- Diagnostics & Clinical grew \(4\%\) .- Academic & Government returned to modest growth of \(1\%\) , despite continued funding pressures in the US.

- All business segments delivered revenue growth ahead of the quarterly guidance.- Life Sciences and Diagnostics Markets Group (LDG) was up \(7\%\) , driven by LDD growth from LC and LC/MS instruments, related to the recent Infinity III launch and focused LC/MS solutions for key applications of both Pharma and applied end markets. NASD grew in the high 20s. BIOVECTRA delivered on expectations despite a planned facility shutdown.- Agilent CrossLab Group (ACG) was up \(5\%\) . Consumables grew MSD despite the \(15M\) tariff-driven pull-forward in Q2; e-commerce and digital orders supported the growth. Services grew MSD. Lab activity remains strong.- Applied Markets Group (AMG) grew \(5\%\) , with GC, GC/MS, and spectroscopy delivering strong growth in Chemicals & Advanced Materials, Food, and Pharma markets. All regions delivered growth, led by Asia ex-China and EMEA, which was driven by re-shoring investments, greenfield opportunities, capacity expansion, and replacement.

- vs. prior year, gross margin was down due to FX, tariffs, and BIOVECTRA (had a planned facility shutdown to expand capacity, but met expectations for the quarter).- vs. guide, operating margin was lighter than expected due to higher than expected tariff costs related to increased volume, increased variable pay expectations related to the pay-for-performance culture, and incremental commercial spend to support short/long term revenue growth. The commercial investments set the company up to capture share from replacement cycles and market demands in 2026.

- Tariffs: Tariff costs were higher than expected in the quarter due to higher order volume. The company estimates tariff-related cost to be \(\) 35M\(in Q4, but expects to offset that through cost reductions or other measures. In our call back, management shared that they expect the tariff impact to "trickle down" as pricing impact takes place, but that will take time. The company expects to fully mitigate tariffs in 2026.

- Pharma spending: Expecting a relatively standard year-end in terms of budget flush. Customer budgets are starting to normalize, and the company has been seeing larger value quotes. The company expects the global redistribution of small molecule supply chains to be a net tailwind. Biopharma with venture capital funding remains conservative with capital budgets, but the company expects those budget will be steadily released over time as interest rates come down. US biopharma spending continues to be muted as expected, but the company has not seen concerns about MFN or tariffs translating into lower spend for large pharma. Management also noted that CapEx purchase approvals are now easier, with less reliance on executive-level approvals that previously delayed or halted spending.
- Pricing: saw 100 bps improvement in pricing during the quarter, vs. 50 bps improvement in the prior year.

- Pull-forward/stocking: Pull-forward in consumables last quarter worked itself out "very, very quickly." Management did not see signs of any additional pull-forward or stocking. Lab activity remains "very, very strong."
- NASD/CDMO: NASD grew in the high 20s. BIOVECTRA met expectations despite a planned facility shutdown to expand capacity. GLP-1s also continue to drive demand.

- PFAS: PFAS grew LDD globally YoY in Q3, despite facing tough comp of \(\sim 50\%\) growth last year. The year-to-date growth is \(50\%\) . In Americas, the business was down \(20\%\) due to US EPA changes, which didn't impact testing volume (and which aren't rooted in any specific policy changes) but added uncertainty around CapEx spend.

EXHIBIT 6: Agilent portfolio overview as of 2022 (i.e., before BIOVECTRA acquisition, new organizational structure)

Life Sciences &amp; Applied Markets GroupLC &amp; LC-MS (30%, $1.2B)Liquid Chromatography is an analytical technique used to separate and purify a mixture of liquids based on differences in physical properties. Often, LC instruments are attached to a Mass Spectrometer that identifies the purified component by measuring its mass-to-charge ratio.GC &amp; GC-MS (19%, $750M)Gas Chromatography is like LC, but it separates a mixture of gases rather than liquids. GC is common in industrial/applied applications.(59% $4.0B)Spectroscopy (15%, $600M)Spectroscopy helps identify compounds by measuring the spectra produced when matter interacts with or emits electromagnetic radiation.Cell Analysis (11%, $450M)Cell analysis instruments are generally designed to study living cells. This includes cell counters, cell analyzers/imaging systems, and flow cytometers. Built primarily from M&A since 2015 and is applicable to many novel modalities.Consumables (25%, $1.0B)Agilent offers a variety of consumables to go along with their instrument offerings, including reagents, chromatography columns, and sample prep kits.Diagnostics &amp; Genomics GroupOligo Manufacturing (21%, $300M)Agilent produces oligonucleotide APIs for clinical and commercial purposes for over 30 Pharma and Biotech partners. The Train B expansion project is coming online now (adds ~$150M in annual rev.) and the company announced Train C&amp;D expansions to come online in 2026/27 and add ~$450M in rev.Cancer Diagnostics (41%, $575M)This portfolio is largely a result of the Dako acquisition in 2012. Includes pathology, specific proteins and flow cytometry reagents, and companion diagnostics (~14% market share)(20% $1.4B)Genomics Solutions (38%, $525M)This includes target enrichment, cytogenic research solutions and microarrays, PCR and qPCR instruments and molecular biology reagents, and automated electrophoresis and microfluidics solutions.ServicesWhile the majority of Agilent's service offerings are break-fix for their own instrument systems, ~10% of ACG is enterprise services where they manage the lab for customers and provide services for competitors products as well.Agilent CrossLab Group (21%, $1.5B)
\\*Revenues are based on FY22 numbers Source: Company reports, Bernstein analysis and estimates

On April 1, 2024, Société Générale (SG) and AllianceBernstein, LP. (AB) completed a transaction that created a new joint venture in which their respective cash equities and research businesses operate in a new business combination. Although their respective ownership percentages in the joint venture differ between North America and the rest of the world, the creation, production and publication of research is handled collaboratively on a global basis across the two research brands, "Bernstein" and "Autonomous". Unless specifically noted otherwise, for purposes of these disclosures, references to Bernstein's "affiliates" relate to both SG and AB and their respective affiliates.

We arrive at our price target of \(\) 125\(by taking the average of a DCF, PE multiple, and EV/EBITDA multiple approach (rounded to nearest\) \ \(5\) increment). Our DCF valuation of \(\) 121\(uses a WACC of\) 9.5\% \(and a terminal growth rate of\) 4.5\% \(. Our PE multiple valuation of\) \ \(133\) uses a \(22\times 2026E\) earnings multiple. Our EV/EBITDA valuation of \(\) 119\(uses a\) 18\times 2026E\(EBITDA multiple.
The key upside risks for Agilent are:
Signs we are at the end of the instrument demand slowdown That the growth strategies transform Agilent more than expected
The key downside risks for Agilent are:
If the instrument slowdown persists for longer than expected If Agilent is unable to cash in on its growth strategies

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp Market- Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within \(+ / - 15\) pp Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. As our benchmarks we use the Bloomberg Europe 500 Banks And Financial Services Index (BEBANKS) and Bloomberg Europe Dev Mkt Financials Large and Mid Cap Price Ret Index EUR (EDMFI) index for developed European banks and Payments, the Bloomberg Europe 500 Insurance Index (BEINSUR) for European insurers, the S&P 500 and S&P Financials for US banks and Payments coverage, S5LIFE for US Insurance, the S&P Insurance Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non- Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:

Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 pp- Neutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within \(+ / - 10\) pp- Underperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12- month time horizon.
